case_name: Bhagwan Kaur v. Maharaj Krishan Sharma and Shanti Devi

facts.text: Maharaj Krishan Sharma (34) and his mother Shanti Devi (55) were convicted by Additional Sessions Judge Delhi under section 302/34 IPC for causing death of Shanti Devi alias Prem Lata (25), wife of Maharaj Krishan, by pouring sulphuric acid in her mouth, sentenced to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: Maharaj Krishan Sharma  34  and his mother Shanti Devi  55  were companyvicted by the Additional Sessions Judge Delhi under section 302 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code on the allegation that they caused the death of Shanti Devi alias Prem Lata  25 , wife of Maharaj Krishan accused, by forcibly pouring sulphuric acid in her mouth, and were sentenced to undergo imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Delhi High Court acquitted the two accused on appeal, giving benefit of doubt.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Delhi High Court acquitted the two accused by giving them the benefit of doubt.

facts.text: Bhagwan Kaur, mother of deceased Shanti Devi, filed special leave appeal against acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal was thereafter filed by Bhagwan Kaur, mother of Shanti Devi deceased, by special leave against the acquittal of the two accused respondents.

facts.text: Shanti Devi (deceased) married Maharaj Krishan on February 20, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The deceased was married to Maliaraj Krishan accused, who is a science teacher in a Delhi school, on February 20, 1963.

facts.text: Accused unhappy with dowry, strained relations, ill-treatment complaints by deceased.

anchor.surface_text: The accused, it is stated, did number feel happy with the dowry brought by the deceased. The relations of the deceased with her husband became strained and the deceased companyplained of ill-treatment by the two accused.

facts.text: In May 1964, Maharaj Krishan obtained writing from deceased stating she wanted divorce.

anchor.surface_text: In May 1964 Maharaj Krishan accused obtained a writing from the deceased in which she stated that she wanted divorce.

facts.text: Hanuman Singh peon purchased one quart of 98.9% sulphuric acid for accused's college on January 13, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On January 13, 1965 Hanuman Singh peon of that 10-L499Sup.C.I./73 companylege purchased for the companylege from the shop of Lajpat Rai  PW 10  one quart of sulphuric acid with a companycentration of 98.9 per cent in a bottle.

facts.text: Towards end of June 1965, Maharaj Krishan demanded money for UK employment, refused by mother-in-law Bhagwan Kaur.

anchor.surface_text: Towards the end of June, Maharaj Krishan accused sent a message through the deceased to his father-in-law that he wanted some money for going to the United Kingdom as he had obtained an employment voucher from the United Kingdom.

facts.text: On July 21, 1965, Shanti Devi telephoned mother Bhagwan Kaur that she was beaten by husband for money demand.

anchor.surface_text: On July 21, 1965, it is stated, Shanti Devi deceased sent a telephonic message to her mother Bhagwan Kaur from the house of the accused that she was being beaten by her husband.

facts.text: Incident occurred on July 23, 1965 around noon; deceased went to neighbor Sushila Devi (PW9), who found her crying on carpet with burning sensation, froth from mouth, became unconscious after saying 'Radhaswami'.

anchor.surface_text: The present occurrence took place on July 23, 1965. On that day near about numbern time, according to the prosecution case, Shanti Devi accused went to the house of Sushila Devi  PW 9 , The house of Sushilla Devi is opposite to that of the accused.

facts.text: Maharaj Krishan called Dr. Tilak Rai Chadha (PW30) around 2 p.m. on July 23, 1965; doctor arrived, saw acid on carpet, charred tongue, advised hospital, called police.

anchor.surface_text: According to this doctor, at about 2 p.m. on that day he received a telephonic message from Maharaj Krishan accused that there was a serious case and that the doctor must reach his  Maharaj Krishans  house at once.

facts.text: Deceased taken to Willingdon Hospital by taxi with Dr. Chadha, Maharaj Krishan, Head Constable Sita Ram (PW29).

anchor.surface_text: A taxi was then brought and the deceased was put in that taxi and taken to the Willingdon Hospital. Head Constable Sita Ram  PW 29  arrived at the house of the accused when the deceased was being taken in the taxi to the Willingdon Hospital.

facts.text: Deceased unfit for statement per doctor; Dayal Das (PW5, father) informed ~4:30 p.m., arrived with Bhagwan Kaur.

anchor.surface_text: At about 4.30 p.m. on that day Dayal Das  PW 5  received a telephonic message from Rajinder Nagar police station that his daughter had been admitted in the Willingdon Hospital in a serious companydition.

facts.text: Around midnight July 23-24, 1965, deceased wrote dying declaration (PW1/A) implicating husband and mother-in-law pouring drug/acid in mouth.

anchor.surface_text: At about mid-night hour, it is alleged, Shanti Devi deceased regained companysciousness and opened her eyes. Bhagwan Kaur asked the deceased as to what had happened, but the deceased companyld number speak and made a gesture indicating that she would Eke to write something.

facts.text: Deceased orally told Bhagwan Kaur and Kamla (PW2) that accused put acid on her tongue.

anchor.surface_text: when Bhagwan Kaur insisted upon the deceased speaking something, the deceased told Bhagwan Kaur that the two accused had put acid on her tongue.

facts.text: Shanti Devi died at about 10:45 a.m. on July 24, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The companydition of Shanti Devi deceased deteriorated in the morning, and she died at about 10.45 a.m.

facts.text: Post mortem by Dr. R.L. Handa on July 25, 1965 at 2:30 p.m.: death due to corrosive acid poisoning; quantity (half to one ounce) could not be forced by another.

anchor.surface_text: Post mortem examination on the body of Shanti Devi deceased was performed by Dr. R. L. Handa at 2.30 p.m. on July 25, 1965. The doctor expressed the opinion that the death of the deceased was due to companyrosive poisoning probably by acid.

facts.text: Bhagwan Kaur filed complaint on June 1, 1966 under 302/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On June 1, 1966 Bhagwan Kaur filed a companyplaint against the accused under section 302 read with section 34 Indian Penal Code on the above allegations.

facts.text: Accused claimed deceased committed suicide by swallowing sulphuric acid.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial the two accused, while number denying the strained relations with the deceased, stated that the deceased had died because she had herself swallowed sulfuric acid.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding death was suicide, not homicide.

anchor.surface_text: We have heard in this Court Mr. Churcharan Singh on behalf of the appellant and Mr. Nooridin on behalf of the respon- dents and are of the opinion that the present appeal is devoid of any merit.

facts.text: No injuries other than acid burns on deceased's body; no such injuries on accused.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor also did number find any marks of injuries on the body of the deceased other than the burns. ... The material on the record also indicates that numbersuch injuries were found on the person of the accused.

facts.text: Police initially reported case as suicide on February 17, 1966; magistrate cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: On February 17, 1966 the police submitted a report to the magistrate, that the case should be cancelled as the evidence indicated that the death of the deceased was the result of suicide.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in an appeal under article 136 of the Constitution does number numbermally reappraise evidence unless it finds Some glaring infirmity in the judgment of the High Court as might have resulted in miscarriage of justice.
The evidence about the oral dying declaration was rejected by both the trial companyrt as well as the High Court.

holdings.text: The present appeal is devoid of any merit and is accordingly dismissed, upholding the High Court's acquittal as the death was a result of suicide, not homicide under section 302/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: We have heard in this Court Mr. Churcharan Singh on behalf of the appellant and Mr. Nooridin on behalf of the respon- dents and are of the opinion that the present appeal is devoid of any merit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court properly appraised evidence pointing to suicide; no infirmities warranting reappraisal; dying declaration unreliable; medical and circumstantial evidence supports suicide.

holdings.text: There is no glaring infirmity in the High Court judgment warranting reappraisal of evidence by the Supreme Court under Article 136 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court arrived at well-reasoned conclusion after proper appraisal; no miscarriage of justice.

holdings.text: The written dying declaration PW 1/A is full of infirmities and improbabilities and is not acceptable as evidence implicating the accused.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the dying declaration PW 1/ A, the learned judges took the view that there were inherent weaknesses and improbabilities which furnished intrinsic evidence against the acceptance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent weaknesses (unusual assurances, unnecessary details, inconsistent signatures, firm hand inconsistent with condition); delay in reporting; unconvincing circumstances.

holdings.text: The circumstances of the case point to the inference that the death of the deceased was the result of suicide.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Medical evidence (quantity of acid, no injuries); accused conduct consistent with innocence; early suicide version by accused; delay in dying declaration story.

holdings.text: The medical evidence indicates that the quantity of acid found could not have been forced into the stomach by another person, supporting suicide over homicide.

anchor.surface_text: According to Dr. Handa, who performed post mortem exami- nation on the body of the deceased, the quantity of acid which was found in the stomach of the deceased was so much that it could not be poured by someone else.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-mortem findings (half to one ounce, perforations, no resistance injuries); consistent with medical jurisprudence texts on rarity of homicidal acid ingestion.

holdings.text: No marks of injuries on the body of the deceased or accused other than burns, inconsistent with forcible administration of acid.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor also did not find any marks of injuries on the body of the deceased other than the burns. ... The material on the record also indicates that no such injuries were found on the person of the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of abrasions or scratches belies prosecution version of forcible holding and pouring.

holdings.text: Evidence of handwriting expert is generally of frail character and little weight should be given to it regarding authorship of the dying declaration.

anchor.surface_text: the prosecution led evidence of handwriting expert to show the similarity of handwriting between PW I A and other admitted writings of the deceased, but in this respect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fallibilities noted; indecisive, yields to positive evidence; cites precedent (Sri Sri Kishore Chandra Singh Deo).

holdings.text: The oral dying declaration was rightly rejected by the trial court and High Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No cogent ground to differ from lower courts' rejection.

precedents.cited_proposition: conclusions based upon mere comparison of handwriting must at best be indecisive and yield to the positive evidence in the case
